awd_titl_txt: U.S.-Japan Seminar:  Electromagnetic Field Effects Caused   by High Voltage Systems June 1994/Sapporo, Japan
awd_abstract_narration: 9315416  Sebo    This awards supports the participation of seven  U.S. scientists and engineers in a U.S.-Japan  Seminar on Electromagnetic Field Effects Caused  by High Voltage Systems, scheduled for June 1994  in Sapporo, Japan.  The co-organizers are  Professor Stephen Sebo, Department of Electrical  Engineering, Ohio State University, and Professor  Katsuo Isaka, Department of Electrical and  Electronic Engineering, University of Tokushima,  Tokushima, Japan.  In addition to the U.S. and  Japanese participants, scientists from Malaysia  and Sweden will take part in the seminar.    The seminar deals with a fundamental and complex  scientific subject.  Many key elements of highly  advanced social system are sensitive to  electromagnetic interference.  The electric power  generation-transmission-distribution systems,  computer-communication-information-control  systems of any kind, radio and television  stations, national security, and social  institutions are examples for such elements.   Electric power systems themselves are also causes  of electromagnetic interference.      The seminar will address these main subjects:   (1) modeling, characterization, and evaluation of  the electric power system related to  electromagnetic fields; (2) studies related to  the environmental effects of high voltage  transmission systems, including possible  biological effects, human perception, and  telephone system performance; and (3) measurement  techniques of electromagnetic fields covering a  broad frequency range, including procedures and  standardization.  ***
